Lack enough support: The claim of free distribution of cycles lacks enough support as it is based on a rumor circulating on Whatsapp and there is no credible evidence or official announcement from the Indian government.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the government has launched a scheme to provide free cycles to youngsters, but there is no confirmation or verification of this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that these websites are fraudulent and trying to collect personal information from users by posing as government schemes. The presence of similar websites with different schemes raises doubts about the authenticity of the claims.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no official government announcement or reliable source confirming the free distribution of cycles scheme.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the availability and distribution of free cycles by stating that all boys and girls will receive them for free, without providing any evidence or details about the source or funding of such a scheme.
Falters at times: The claim falters in terms of credibility and reliability as it is spread through rumors on social media platforms and lacks verifiable information.
Understate: There is no understatement bias evident in the claim.
